body:
Try adding `--disable ListR` - does that fix it?

If so then this is the new ListR code.

The new ListR code will list your entire onedrive just to select the one file from `Test` so this is probably the worst possible case for it.

Does it work eventually if you leave it running? How many files do you have on your onedrive in total? Does `rclone size onedrive:` work?

> Try adding `--disable ListR` - does that fix it?

This indeed solves the problem and results are provided immediately.

> If so then this is the new ListR code.

Looks like that.

> The new ListR code will list your entire onedrive just to select the one file from `Test` so this is probably the worst possible case for it.
> 
> Does it work eventually if you leave it running? How many files do you have on your onedrive in total? Does `rclone size onedrive:` work?

When I leave it running it actually provides results after about 15 min - the same as size for all onedrive: (which has about 500k files in total I think)

Good that we have explanation but not good that ListR is used in the way benefiting only specific use-cases.

I need some ideas here!

Using ListR works fantastically well on onedrive for listing all your files, eg when prefilling your VFS cache. See #7317 for the conversation.

Unfortunately the API only lists from the root and not from a given directory.

And you've hit pretty much the worst possible case!

Ideas
- revert the change (and make unhappy VFS users)
- keep the change (and make `rclone size` on a small directory in a big onedrive take forever)
- have a flag to turn it on and off (not particularly happy about that but it would work - what would the default be?)
- Only use it at the root. This is 100% safe but would probably make the VFS users unhappy since it is quite common to not mount the root (eg a crypt).
- Only use it at the root or if wrapped in a crypt.
- Some sort of clever heuristic. If ListR runs for more than X seconds or for more than Y files without finding any files to list (ie all files found are outside the current directory) abort and retry with conventional recursive listing.
- ListR could check `rclone about` to see the total file size and do something (unfortunately we don't get total number of files)

Can you think of anything else? Any thoughts on the above?

It is indeed quite a few things to consider... 

To get any meaningful ideas I think it might be beneficial to try to understand it a bit more. Let's start with `rclone size` and ListR. I have run multiple tests on whole onedrive: remote and I do not see any benefit of ListR from latest beta - on the contrary - it is much slower:

```
--> v1.64
$ time rclone size onedrive2:
Total objects: 188.886k (188886)
Total size: 663.248 GiB (712157426697 Byte)

real	2m18.049s
user	0m12.377s
sys	0m4.151s

--> v1.65 with ListR
$ time ~/Temp/rclone-beta/rclone size onedrive2:
Total objects: 188.886k (188886)
Total size: 663.248 GiB (712157426697 Byte)

real	8m21.174s
user	0m12.415s
sys	0m3.158s
```

beta is 4 times slower. I have re-run these test few times to make sure it is not some random network glitch.

I do understand that before I used worst case scenario but by running `rclone size` against all remote I thought I would do best case scenario. What am I missing here?

And when v1.64 takes only seconds for smaller folders the latest beta always takes 8min+. Am I missing here something about ListR benefits? For `rclone size` it is always much slower than before - I can not see single case when it brings any improvement.

I think the main benefit comes when the `--disable ListR` list starts throttling. Because the `ListR` uses the delta changes API which is recommended by Microsoft, it does not get throttled.

Fundamentally the `ListR` is single threaded whereas the `--disable ListR` will be using `--checkers` listing threads so is doing stuff in parallel.

It probably depends on exactly your layout of directories which is faster and which is slower.

@jcastilloalonso I would love your experiences on this too. Can you repeat this test on your data? Both using the beta.

    time rclone size onedrive:

vs

    time rclone size onedrive: --disable ListR

I am leaning towards making this controlled by a flag but more input would be good.

I tried this test on a personal onedrive and a business onedrive and in both cases the `--disable ListR` was faster, 60% for the personal, 20% for the business.

However on #7317 times were reported going from 5 minutes with `ListR` to 1 Hour (without).

This is on my 25TB OneDrive Business OneDrive:

```
# time ./rclone size one:
Total objects: 42.880k (42880)
Total size: 19.935 TiB (21918950374345 Byte)

real    1m22.691s
user    0m7.491s
sys     0m0.926s
# time ./rclone size one: --disable ListR
Total objects: 42.880k (42880)
Total size: 19.935 TiB (21918950374345 Byte)

real    13m14.045s
user    0m20.368s
sys     0m6.160s
```

It's not even comparable with big structures.

Yet I agree it is going to be slower if you are just selecting some subdata.

```
# time ./rclone size one:Family
Total objects: 79 (79)
Total size: 133.805 GiB (143672349200 Byte)

real    1m1.474s
user    0m6.449s
sys     0m0.916s
# time ./rclone size one:Family --disable ListR
Total objects: 79 (79)
Total size: 133.805 GiB (143672349200 Byte)

real    0m1.047s
user    0m0.332s
sys     0m0.076s
```

@ncw  it might make sense to detault to old implementation and maybe add a new flag --onedrive-delta to activate ListR and delta? The way I see it, the speed difference is only noticeable/usuable for people holding a lot of information, in my scenario.

Heres a smaller OneDrive Business account:
```
# time ./rclone size onesc:
Total objects: 78.277k (78277)
Total size: 286.791 GiB (307939717984 Byte)
real    2m9.731s
user    0m6.983s
sys     0m0.770s
# time ./rclone size onesc: --disable ListR
Total objects: 78.277k (78277)
Total size: 286.791 GiB (307939717984 Byte)

real    1m12.018s
user    0m15.636s
sys     0m3.113s
```

And my personal OneDrive I got an errorwith the disable ListR flag:

```
# time ./rclone size One:
Total objects: 103.989k (103989)
Total size: 901.875 GiB (968380839761 Byte)

real    5m29.908s
user    0m11.103s
sys     0m1.543s
# time ./rclone size One: --disable ListR
2023/10/16 11:31:27 ERROR : Documents: error listing: unknown object type <nil>
2023/10/16 11:32:10 ERROR : UnknownError: : upload chunks may be taking too long - try reducing --onedrive-chunk-size or decreasing --transfers
2023/10/16 11:33:57 Failed to size with 2 errors: last error was: unknown object type <nil>
real    2m30.953s
user    0m12.242s
sys     0m1.886s
```

Definitely it should be something which should be turned on/off. It brings clear benefits in specific situation but can make things much worse in others.

I would leave default as it is now - simply to not create behaviour braking change. Example is my usage where I use `rclone size` in multiple bash scripts. Of course I can add `--disable ListR` if needed but I think that existing way should not change by introducing new enhancements. Unless it provides clear benefits across all situations - which is not the case here.

I have added a `--onedrive-delta` flag as suggested which will default to off. So you will need to enable this feature with `delta = true` in the config file or `--onedrive-delta` on the command line.

This will go into 1.65

issue.title: Bring delta support to OneDrive/Sharepoint remote

repository.name: rclone
repository.description: "rsync for cloud storage" - Google Drive, S3, Dropbox, Backblaze B2, One Drive, Swift, Hubic, Wasabi, Google Cloud Storage, Azure Blob, Azure Files, Yandex Files

issue.body:
<!--

Welcome :-)

So you've got an idea to improve rclone? We love that!
You'll be glad to hear we've incorporated hundreds of ideas from contributors already.

Probably the latest beta (or stable) release has your feature, so try to update your rclone.
The update instructions are available at https://rclone.org/commands/rclone_selfupdate/

If it still isn't there, here is a checklist of things to do:

  1. Search the old issues for your idea and +1 or comment on an existing issue if possible.
  2. Discuss on the forum: https://forum.rclone.org/
  3. Make a feature request issue (this is the right place!).
  4. Be prepared to get involved making the feature :-)

Looking forward to your great idea!

The Rclone Developers

-->

#### The associated forum post URL from `https://forum.rclone.org`

https://forum.rclone.org/t/possible-listr-support-for-onedrive-sharepoint/41832/4?u=jcastill

#### What is your current rclone version (output from `rclone version`)?

1.64.0

#### What problem are you are trying to solve?

Currently OneDrive does not support ListR, yet it seems that implementing delta (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/onedrive/developer/rest-api/concepts/scan-guidance?view=odsp-graph-online) would allow for ListR to be functional on the remote. This would help a lot specially as Microsoft is very conservative on TPSLimit before throttling so a list command of a large folder structure can easily trigger a throttle event.

Seems delta also supports single files/sub folders so it does not need to always scan the whole drive (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/api/driveitem-delta?view=graph-rest-1.0&tabs=http)

#### How do you think rclone should be changed to solve that?

This can be used when --fast-list is invoked to scan the whole subfolder in less API calls in lieu of using more RAM. This can also be used for polling once a scan is completed, not sure if it would only work if initial scan is used by delta, in which case it might make sense to make it default for the remote as it's part of Microsoft API best practices.


<!--- Please keep the note below for others who read your feature request. -->

#### How to use GitHub

* Please use the ðŸ‘ [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are affected by the same issue.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

body:
> I have added a `--onedrive-delta` flag as suggested which will default to off. So you will need to enable this feature with `delta = true` in the config file or `--onedrive-delta` on the command line.
> 
> This will go into 1.65

Thank you for remembering this. Works perfectly.

> Thank you for remembering this. Works perfectly.

I almost forgot but I realised that it was missing when I was writing the release notes !
